facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th September, 1956 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 8th December, 1955 of the Sessions Judge, Birbhum in Sessions Trial No. 1 of November 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 12th September 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th September, 1956 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 8th December, 1955 of the Sessions Judge, Birbhum in Sessions Trial No. 1 of November 1955. J. Umrigar and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated 8th December 1955 of Sessions Judge Birbhum in Sessions Trial No. 1 of November 1955

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 8th December, 1955 of the Sessions Judge, Birbhum in Sessions Trial No. 1 of November 1955. J. Umrigar and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant. B. Bagchi, P. K. Ghosh for P. K. Bose, for the respondent. 1959. May 8.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to imprisonment for life under s. 302 by Sessions Judge of Birbhum

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was sentenced to imprisonment for life under s. 302 by the Sessions Judge of Birbhum who agreed with the majority verdict of the jury that he was guilty. He appealed against his conviction to the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Sessions Judge agreed with majority verdict of jury that appellant guilty

anchor.surface_text: who agreed with the majority verdict of the jury that he was guilty. He appealed against his conviction to the Calcutta High Court. That Court being of the opinion that there was no misdirection in the Sessions Judges charge to the jury dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Jagdish Gorain and Sudhir Gorain tried along with appellant, acquitted by jury, verdict accepted by Sessions Judge

anchor.surface_text: Two persons Jagdish Gorain and Sudhir Gorain were also tried along with the appellant but were acquitted by the jury whose verdict the Sessions Judge accepted. The appellant appealed to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed appellant's appeal

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused. The present appeal is by special leave. According to the prosecution Sibapada Hati was married to a girl by the name of Lila.

facts.text: Sibapada Hati married to Lila

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution Sibapada Hati was married to a girl by the name of Lila. About a month previous to the date of occurrence the appellant had made a proposal to her that she should live with him which was rejected.

facts.text: About a month previous to occurrence, appellant proposed to Lila that she live with him, rejected

anchor.surface_text: About a month previous to the date of occurrence the appellant had made a proposal to her that she should live with him which was rejected. The appellant thought that the removal of Sibapada Hati would clear the way and improve his chance of gaining Lilas favour.

facts.text: Appellant murdered Sibapada Hati on May 26 1955

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he murdered Sibapada Hati on the May 26, 1955. In that murder he was assisted by Jagdish Gorain, Sudhir Gorain and the approver Sastipada Ghose. The conviction of the appellant depended on the evidence of the approver and the circumstantial evidence

facts.text: Assisted by Jagdish Gorain, Sudhir Gorain and approver Sastipada Ghose

anchor.surface_text: In that murder he was assisted by Jagdish Gorain, Sudhir Gorain and the approver Sastipada Ghose. The conviction of the appellant depended on the evidence of the approver and the circumstantial evidence which corroborated him in connecting or tending to connect the appellant

facts.text: On 25th May 1955 appellant came to Lilas house and talked with deceased

anchor.surface_text: There was a motive for the appellant to commit the, crime, that is to say, his immoral proposal to Lila, wife of the deceased. On the 25th of May, 1955, the appellant came to Lilas house and had a talk with the deceased.

facts.text: On 26th May 1955 morning appellant came to house and talked with deceased

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th of May, 1955, in the morning the appellant also came to the house and talked with the deceased. Later on that very day a little after sunset the appellant came to the house and asked the deceased to go for a walk with him.

facts.text: On 26th May 1955 little after sunset appellant asked deceased to go for walk, deceased did

anchor.surface_text: Later on that very day a little after sunset the appellant came to the house and asked the deceased to go for a walk with him. The deceased did so. Thereafter the appellant was seen going with Jagdish Gorain and the deceased-by Brojeswari and Lila

facts.text: Appellant seen going with Jagdish Gorain and deceased by Brojeswari and Lila towards north of village after 5 pm

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant was seen going with Jagdish Gorain and the deceased-by Brojeswari and Lila towards the north of the village after 5 p.m. while they were bathing in Talbona tank. According to the approver at the time that the, deceased was stabbed

facts.text: Approver stated appellant sustained injury on dorsum of left palm while stabbing deceased

anchor.surface_text: According to the approver at the time that the, deceased was stabbed by the appellant he had sustained an injury on the dorsum of his left palm. The medical evidence established that the appellant had an almost healed up ulcer I inch in length

facts.text: Medical evidence: appellant had almost healed ulcer 1 inch on left side of palm posterior surface 1 inch below wrist joint and 1/3 inch on left thumb posterior surface, could be caused by sharp cutting weapon like knife

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence established that the appellant had an almost healed up ulcer I inch in length on the left side of the palm at its posterior surface one inch below the wrist joint and another healed up ulcer 1/3 inch in length on the left thumb at the posterior surface and that these injuries could be caused by a sharp cutting weapon like a knife.

facts.text: Night of 26 May 1955, Brojeswari and uncle Radharaman Sadhu searched for deceased at club-house where appellant, Jagdish, Sudhir, approver associated

anchor.surface_text: As it had become night and the deceased had not returned, Lilas mother Brojeswari and. her uncle Radharaman Sadhu searched for him. They went to the club-house where the appellant and his two co-accused Jagdish Gorain and Sudhir Gorain and the approver used to associate with each other.

facts.text: Appellant first replied to Brojeswari that deceased had not gone with him, did not know whereabouts

anchor.surface_text: When enquiries were made from the appellant by Brojeswari he first replied that the deceased had not gone with him and that he did not know anything about his whereabouts. When he was reminded that it was he who had taken the deceased for a walk which he was denying,

facts.text: Appellant then said deceased went with him up to canal north of village, but as he felt a headache he came away, no news of deceased

anchor.surface_text: the appellant replied that the deceased went with him upto the canal towards north of the village, but as he felt a headache he came away and it was not possible for the appellant to give any news about the deceaseds whereabouts.

facts.text: There was motive for appellant: immoral proposal to Lila wife of deceased

anchor.surface_text: As to the 3rd Submission made on behalf of the appellant the following circumstances were established by the evidence which were accepted by the jury There was a motive for the appellant to commit the, crime, that is to say, his immoral proposal to Lila, wife of the deceased.

facts.text: Jury acquitted Jagdish Gorain

anchor.surface_text: Two persons Jagdish Gorain and Sudhir Gorain were also tried along with the appellant but were acquitted by the jury whose verdict the Sessions Judge accepted.

facts.text: No motive for Jagdish Gorain to commit murder

anchor.surface_text: As to the 4th submission that although there was similar corroboration of the approvers evidence against Jagdish Gorain but he had been acquitted by the jury although no real distinction between his case and the case of the appellant arose is unsound as, in our opinion, the two cases are not comparable. In the first place, there was no motive for Jagdish Gorain to commit the murder.

facts.text: Jagdish received injury while catching knife from appellant saying what have you done, tending to prevent further stabbing

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, the injury which Jagdish received was while he caught the knife in the hand of the appellant saying what have you done? The approvers evidence therefore rather tended to show that he tried to prevent the appellant from further stabbing the deceased.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate to appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused. The present appeal is by special leave.

The appellant was sentenced to imprisonment for life under s. 302 by the Sessions Judge of Birbhum who agreed with the majority verdict of the jury that he was guilty. He appealed against his conviction to the Calcutta High Court.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th September, 1956 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 8th December, 1955 of the Sessions Judge, Birbhum in Sessions Trial No. 1 of November 1955. J. Umrigar and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.
The appellant appealed to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was refused. The present appeal is by special leave.

The Sessions Judge in dealing with the evidence of the approver charged the jury as follows- Before doing so, some established legal principles as regards the approvers evidence and the confessions on which the prosecution has relied in the present case are required to be explained to you. The approver is a competent witness against an accused person and although his evidence is strictly admissible and a conviction is not illegal, merely because it is based on approvers evidence, it is a settled rule of practice not to convict a person on such evidence except under very rare and exceptional circumstances, and usually substantial corroboration is required. I, therefore, warn you, gentlemen, that it is highly dangerous to convict on approvers evidence alone.

concepts.interpretation: Settled rule of practice requiring substantial corroboration for approver's evidence as it is dangerous to convict solely on it, though legally permissible; corroboration must be independent, confirm crime and connect accused to it.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the High Court. We have examined the charge to the jury. The Sessions Judge in dealing with the evidence of the approver charged the jury as follows-

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule of practice that conviction on uncorroborated approver evidence is highly dangerous; requires material corroboration connecting accused to crime.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar on behalf of the appellant urged that the aforesaid direction given by Sessions Judge to the jury was not sufficient. The jury should have been told 1 in accordance with the decision of this Court in the case of Sarwan Singh v. The State of Punjab 1 that the approvers evidence has to satisfy a double test. It must show that he is a reliable witness and that his evidence receives sufficient corroboration, 2 that the evidence of an approver must be confirmed not only as to the circumstances of the crime but also as to the identity of the prisoner.

concepts.interpretation: Double test: (1) approver must be reliable witness (common to all witnesses); (2) sufficient corroboration (special to tainted evidence); distinguished here as approver reliable and corroborated.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: g has been shown to us in this case, as was shown in Sarwan Singhs case that apart from the approvers testimony in the present case being regarded as

concepts.unlisted_description: Approver evidence must satisfy reliability and sufficient corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the case of The King v. Baskerville 1 , 3 that the circumstantial evidence corroborating the approver was not sufficient to connect the appellant with the murder of the deceased ... We hold that evidence in corroboration must be independent testimony which affects the accused by connecting or tending to connect him with the crime.

concepts.interpretation: Corroboration must be independent evidence implicating accused by connecting to crime, not just confirming crime occurred; can be circumstantial; same test for rule of practice or statutory requirements.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: mitted the crime. It is sufficient if it is merely circumstantial evidence of his companynection with the crime. The companyroboration in material par

concepts.unlisted_description: Corroborative evidence must implicate the accused by connecting them to the crime.

anchor.surface_text: Unless there was a misdirection or non-direction amounting to a misdirection in the charge to the jury which, in fact, had occasioned a failure of justice the jurys verdict must prevail and it cannot be interfered with. The High Court was of the opinion that there was no misdirection in the Sessions Judges charge to the jury and we are in agreement with the High Court.

concepts.interpretation: Jury verdict prevails unless misdirection or non-direction occasions failure of justice; here, no misdirection found.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: jurys verdict must prevail and it cannot be interfered with. The High Court was of the opinion that there was numbermisdirection in the Sessions Judg

concepts.unlisted_description: Interference with jury verdict only if charge misdirection leads to failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, a previous statement of an approver, viz., the confession has been made exhibit before you, but that previous statement, you are further to bear in mind, cannot corroborate his latter statement, viz., the statements that have been made by him before you in this Court.

concepts.interpretation: Approver's previous confession cannot corroborate his court testimony.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: must be such as to companynect or identify each of the accused with the offence. In the present case, a previous statement of an approver, viz., the

concepts.unlisted_description: Prior confession of approver inadmissible to corroborate his evidence in court.

precedents.citation: Sarwan Singh v. The State of Punjab 1 1957 S.C.R. 953

anchor.surface_text: in the case of Sarwan Singh v. The State of Punjab  1  that the approvers evidence has to satisfy a double test. It must show that he is a reliable witness and that his evidence receives sufficient companyroboration,  2  that the evidence of an approver must be companyfirmed number only as to the circumstances of the crime but also as to the identity of the prisoner. The companyroboration  1  1957 S.C.R. 953. ought to companysist in circumstances that affects the identity of the party accused.

precedents.case_name: Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: approvers evidence has to satisfy a double test: (1) he is a reliable witness and his evidence receives sufficient corroboration; (2) corroboration of approver's evidence as to circumstances of the crime and identity of the accused, consisting in circumstances affecting the identity of the accused
precedents.cited_holding: The appreciation of an approvers evidence has to satisfy a double test. It must show that he is a reliable witness and that his evidence receives sufficient corroboration and that is a test which is common to all witnesses. If this test is satisfied the second test which still remains to be applied is that the approvers evidence must receive sufficient corroboration. This test is special to the cases of weak or tainted evidence like that of the approver.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the case of The King v. Baskerville  1 ,  3  that the circumstantial evidence corroborating the approver was no sufficient to connect the appellant with the murder of the deceased [...] in Baskervilles case the Court of Criminal Appeal in England [...] came to the following conclusion - We hold that evidence in corroboration must be independent testimony which affects the accused by connecting or tending to connect him with the crime. In other words, it must be evidence which implicates him [...] 1 1916 2 K.B.D. 658

precedents.cited_proposition: corroboration must be independent testimony which affects/connects/tends to connect the accused with the crime; implicates the accused by confirming not only that crime was committed but that accused committed it; may be circumstantial evidence of connection with crime
precedents.cited_holding: We hold that evidence in corroboration must be independent testimony which affects the accused by connecting or tending to connect him with the crime. In other words, it must be evidence which implicates him, that is, which confirms in some material particular not only the evidence that the crime has been committed, but also that the prisoner committed it.
